title: How to Multiply Two Digit Numbers Mentally

steps.title: Find the average of the two factors you are multiplying.
steps.content: Find the average of the two factors you are multiplying. To find the average, add both numbers together, then divide by 2. You can also think of this as the number that both factors are equidistant from. [1] X Research source Note that this method only works if the average of the two factors is a whole number. For example, if you are calculating 23 × 17 {\displaystyle 23\times 17} , find the average of 23 and 17: 23 + 17 2 = 40 2 = 20 {\displaystyle {\frac {23+17}{2}}={\frac {40}{2}}=20} So, the average is 20. In other words, 23 and 17 are equidistant from 20.

steps.title: Find the difference between each factor and their average.
steps.content: Find the difference between each factor and their average. This difference should be the same for both numbers. For example, since the average of 23 and 17 is 20, you would calculate 23 − 20 = 3 {\displaystyle 23-20=3} and 20 − 17 = 3 {\displaystyle 20-17=3} . So, the difference between each factor and their average is 3.

steps.title: Recall the formula for the difference of two squares.
steps.content: Recall the formula for the difference of two squares. The formula is ( a + b ) ( a − b ) = a 2 − b 2 {\displaystyle (a+b)(a-b)=a^{2}-b^{2}} [2] X Research source For the purposes of multiplying two 2-digit numbers together, let a {\displaystyle a} equal the average of the two products, and b {\displaystyle b} equal the difference between each factor and their average. [3] X Research source For example, ( 20 + 3 ) ( 20 − 3 ) = 20 2 − 3 2 {\displaystyle (20+3)(20-3)=20^{2}-3^{2}} .

steps.title: Square a {\displaystyle a} and b {\displaystyle b} .
steps.content: Square a {\displaystyle a} and b {\displaystyle b} . Remember that squaring a number means to multiply it by itself. Hopefully these numbers are easy for you to square in your head. If they aren’t, you might need to use another mental math method. For example: ( 20 + 3 ) ( 20 − 3 ) = 20 2 − 3 2 {\displaystyle (20+3)(20-3)=20^{2}-3^{2}} ( 20 + 3 ) ( 20 − 3 ) = 400 − 9 {\displaystyle (20+3)(20-3)=400-9}

steps.title: Calculate the difference between the two squares.
steps.content: Calculate the difference between the two squares. The result will be the product of your original two factors. [4] X Research source For example, ( 20 + 3 ) ( 20 − 3 ) = 391 {\displaystyle (20+3)(20-3)=391} . So, ( 23 ) ( 17 ) = 391 {\displaystyle (23)(17)=391} .

steps.title: Determine which factor is closest to 100.
steps.content: Determine which factor is closest to 100. This method works best when one of the factors is very close to 100, particularly when one of the factors is 99. But, this method may work for other factors as well. For example, you might be multiplying 12 × 98 {\displaystyle 12\times 98} . In this case, 98 is closest to 100.

steps.title: Re-express the factor closest to 100 as 100 − x {\displaystyle 100-x} .
steps.content: Re-express the factor closest to 100 as 100 − x {\displaystyle 100-x} . The variable x {\displaystyle x} represents the difference between the factor and 100. For example, 98 = ( 100 − 2 ) {\displaystyle 98=(100-2)} .

steps.title: Substitute the re-expressed factor into the original equation.
steps.content: Substitute the re-expressed factor into the original equation. You should think about multiplying 100 − x {\displaystyle 100-x} by the smaller factor. For example, 12 × 98 = 12 ( 100 − 2 ) {\displaystyle 12\times 98=12(100-2)} .

steps.title: Multiply using the distributive property.
steps.content: Multiply using the distributive property. Since the first number in parentheses is 100, it should be easy to find the first factor. Finding the second factor is easier the closest the original number is to 100. For example, 12 × 98 = 12 ( 100 − 2 ) = 1 , 200 − 24 {\displaystyle 12\times 98=12(100-2)=1,200-24} .

steps.title: Find the difference between the two products.
steps.content: Find the difference between the two products. This will give you the product of your original two factors. For example, 1 , 200 − 24 = 1 , 176 {\displaystyle 1,200-24=1,176} , so 12 × 98 = 1 , 176 {\displaystyle 12\times 98=1,176} .

steps.title: Determine whether either factor is even.
steps.content: Determine whether either factor is even. You will be halving the even number. [5] X Research source Remember that an even number is one that is divisible by 2. If both factors are even, choose the smaller number to halve. For example, if you are multiplying 15 × 32 {\displaystyle 15\times 32} , you would halve the 32, since it is an even number.

steps.title: Half the even number.
steps.content: Half the even number. To do this, divide by 2. If you know your math facts well, you should be able to do this easily. For example, 32 2 = 16 {\displaystyle {\frac {32}{2}}=16} .

steps.title: Double the other number.
steps.content: Double the other number. To double a number, multiply it by 2. For example, 15 × 2 = 30 {\displaystyle 15\times 2=30} .

steps.title: Consider the new multiplication problem.
steps.content: Consider the new multiplication problem. The new problem is the result of halving one of the factors and doubling the other. For example, 15 × 32 = 30 × 16 {\displaystyle 15\times 32=30\times 16} .

steps.title: Continue the process until you arrive at a problem you can compute mentally.
steps.content: Continue the process until you arrive at a problem you can compute mentally. Make sure you always halve the same number, and double the same number. The amount of times you halve and double should be same for both factors. [6] X Research source For example: 15 × 32 {\displaystyle 15\times 32} = 30 × 16 {\displaystyle =30\times 16} = 60 × 8 {\displaystyle =60\times 8} = 480 {\displaystyle =480}
